1:
Like snow in summer or rain in harvest,\q so a fool does not deserve honor.
\q
2:
As the sparrow flitters and the swallow darts when they fly,\q so an undeserved curse does not alight.


\q
3:
A whip is for the horse, a bridle is for the donkey\q and a rod is for the back of fools.
\q
4:
Do not answer a fool according to his folly,\q or you will become like him.


\q
5:
Answer a fool and join in on his folly,\q so he will not become wise in his own eyes.
\q
6:
Whoever sends a message by the hand of a fool\q cuts off his own feet and drinks violence.


\q
7:
Like the legs of a paralytic which hang down\q is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
\q
8:
Like tying a stone in a sling\q is giving honor to a fool.

\q
9:
Like a thorn that goes into the hand of a drunkard\q is a proverb in the mouth of fools.
\q
10:
Like an archer who wounds all those around him\q is one who hires a fool or hires anyone who passes by.


\q
11:
As a dog returns to his own vomit,\q so is a fool who repeats his folly.
\q
12:
Do you see someone who is wise in his own eyes?\q There is more hope for a fool than for him.


\q
13:
The lazy person says, "There is a lion on the road!\q There is a lion between the open places!"
\q
14:
As the door turns on its hinges,\q so is the lazy person upon his bed.


\q
15:
The lazy person puts his hand into the dish\q and yet he has no strength to lift it up to his mouth.
\q
16:
The lazy person is wiser in his own eyes\q than seven men with discernment.


\q
17:
Like one who takes hold of the ears of a dog,\q is a passerby who becomes angry at a dispute that is not his own.


\q
18: Like a madman who shoots burning arrows,\q
19:
is the one who deceives his neighbor\q and says, "Was I not telling a joke?"


\q
20:
For lack of wood, the fire goes out;\q and where there is no gossiper quarreling ceases.
\q
21:
As charcoal is to burning coals and wood is to fire,\q so is a quarrelsome person for kindling strife.


\q
22:
The words of a gossip are like delicious morsels;\q they go down into the inner parts of the body.
\q
23:
Like the glaze overlaying an earthen vessel\q so are burning lips and an evil heart.



\q
24:
One who hates others disguises his feelings with his lips\q and he lays up deceit within himself.
\q
25:
He will speak graciously, but do not believe him,\q for there are seven abominations in his heart.
\q
26:
Though his hatred is covered with deception,\q his wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.


\q
27:
Whoever digs a pit will fall into it\q and the stone will roll back on the one who pushed it.
\q
28: A lying tongue hates the people it crushes\q and a flattering mouth brings about ruin.
